unnormalised: In layman's terms, criminal law deals with offences committed against society as a whole, not just individuals. Think of it like this: when someone commits a crime, they're not just harming a victim, but also disrupting the peace and safety of the community. This is why the State steps in to prosecute the offender.

unnormalised: The Indian Penal Code (IPC), 1860, forms the backbone of criminal law in India. Sections within the IPC, such as Sec. 302 (murder), Sec. 376 (rape), and Sec. 420 (cheating), define various offences and prescribe punishments for them. It is a comprehensive document, with amendments being made over time to reflect changing societal values and address emerging forms of crime, such as cybercrime. The CrPC, 1973, also known as the Code of Criminal Procedure, lays down the procedure for investigations, arrests, trials, and appeals in criminal cases.
normalised: The Indian Penal Code (I-P-C), one thousand eight hundred and sixty, forms the backbone of criminal law in India. Sections within the I-P-C, such as Section three hundred and two (murder), Section three hundred and seventy six (rape), and Section four hundred and twenty (cheating), define various offenses and prescribe punishments for them. It is a comprehensive document, with amendments being made over time to reflect changing societal values and address emerging forms of crime, such as cybercrime. The C-r-P-C, one thousand nine hundred and seventy three, also known as the Code of Criminal Procedure, lays down the procedure for investigations, arrests, trials, and appeals in criminal cases.

unnormalised: FIR or First Information Report, is a crucial document. It is the first step in the investigation of a cognizable offence (an offence for which a police officer can arrest without a warrant). Any person who has knowledge of the commission of a cognizable offence can file an FIR at the nearest police station. The SHO or Station House Officer is responsible for registering the FIR.
normalised: F-I-R or First Information Report, is a crucial document. It is the first step in the investigation of a cognizable offense (an offense for which a police officer can arrest without a warrant). Any person who has knowledge of the commission of a cognizable offense can file an F-I-R at the nearest police station. The S-H-O or Station House Officer is responsible for registering the F-I-R.

unnormalised: Criminal cases are generally classified as either cognizable or non-cognizable. As explained before, in cognizable cases, the police can arrest the accused without a warrant, while in non-cognizable cases, a warrant is required from a magistrate. Furthermore, offenses are also categorised as bailable or non-bailable. In bailable offences, the accused has a right to bail, while in non-bailable offences, bail is at the discretion of the court.

unnormalised: The prosecution's duty is to prove the guilt of the accused "beyond a reasonable doubt". This means that the evidence presented must be so compelling that no reasonable person would doubt the accused's guilt. The burden of proof lies entirely on the prosecution; the accused is presumed innocent until proven guilty.

unnormalised: The defense lawyer, on the other hand, represents the accused and presents their side of the story. They examine witnesses, present evidence, and argue on behalf of their client. It's their job to ensure that the accused receives a fair trial and that their rights are protected.

unnormalised: A Sessions Court typically handles major criminal cases, such as murder, rape, and dacoity. Magistrate Courts handle lesser offences. High Courts hear appeals from lower courts, and the Supreme Court of India is the final court of appeal. Numerous cases have been registered this year under the act, with at least 1500 filed in Maharashtra in the last month. Judgement on these cases are pending.
